newsitem.title: INDIA: India clinic treating Mother Teresa free of cost.
newsitem.headline: India clinic treating Mother Teresa free of cost.

text.p: Mother Teresa is being treated free of charge at an Indian heart clinic that is sophisticated enough to do heart transplants, officials said on Wednesday.
Mother Teresa's faltering heart has focused attention on an imposing six-storey structure in the heart of India's eastern city of Calcutta, better known for teeming slums than aseptic medical care.
The B.M. Birla Heart Research Centre is treating the revered missionary free as a mark of respect for her work of compassion and caring, a clinic official told Reuters.
"We are bearing the entire medical expenses," Birla administrator S.K. Tiwari said. "She is an important person. She has done such a lot of good work."
Last week Mother Teresa, 86, underwent surgery to clear two blocked arteries. She appeared to be getting better when longstanding lung troubles and kidney difficulties resurfaced.
Mother Teresa's doctors said she has since improved. But her heart beat was still irregular and she remained in critical condition.
Her vital signs were being monitored round-the-clock by two people in the intensive therapy unit on the first floor of the hospital.
Tiwari said the care Mother Teresa had so far received would cost far more than the 105,000-rupee ($2,900) price tag an ordinary patient would pay for two weeks of similar treatment.
Woodlands hospital, where Mother Teresa was treated before being moved to the heart clinic, also waived its charges.
At the Birla clinic, Mother Teresa underwent an angiography followed by an angioplasty, as well as additional intensive care to deal with her complications relating to her age.
Angiography uses an X-ray and opaque dye to check for blockages in blood vessels. Angioplasty uses an inflatable balloon to unblock blood vessels.
The Birla clinic has performed an estimated 15,000 angiograms and angioplasties since opening in 1989, Tiwari said. It has also conducted 6,000 heart bypass operations.
The clinic stands on Calcutta's National Library Road, an upper-class area that seems a world apart from the squalor of the slums where Mother Teresa has spent most of her life.
Facing the clinic is Command House, the residence of the top army officer in eastern India.
The team of doctors treating Mother Teresa is led by the Birla centre's clinical director, Dr D.P. Shetty.
"Dr Shetty did our first open heart bypass surgery when the centre opened in May 1989," said Tiwari. "That first patient is still alive. We often invite him to hospital functions."
Tiwari said there were about 16 heart specialists permanently attached to the clinic. More than 50 others offer their services as visiting staff.

He said the 150-bed hospital was set up at a cost of 350 million rupees ($10 million). It is run by a group that also runs the nearby Calcutta Hospital, a general hospital with 400 beds and about 1,000 staff.
"We have the facilities to do heart transplants," Tiwari said. "But the government is not giving us permission to do so. We have applied many times."
Heart transplants are still a thorny subject for many Indians. The procedure is caught in a complex tangle of legal and ethical issues.
